commits.message: Format question sections
Try cleaned up Data Builder branch

Change `patient_demographics` to `patients`

This moves to using an equivalent table offered by Data Builder's
universal contract, instead of using a special tutorial table.

This in turn reduces the amount of code needed to be added to Data
Builder to make this import work.

Add a `project.yaml` for all the tutorial code

You can run each individually via `opensafely run <job_name>`

This is a start of moving to using the OpenSAFELY CLI to run all the
dataset definitions, at least for users, to make installation and
running the examples easier.
Ignore OpenSAFELY CLI generated `metadata/`

Update `patient_demographics` in Markdown

To `patients`.
Correct some names in `project.yaml`

Pin Data Builder version to an actual release

Instead of an arbitrary branch commit.

The tables needed to make the examples work are now in the `main` branch
and part of the latest release.

Pin the Docker image used for the examples

For now until a better solution is implemented.

We want the Python installed package in the requirements, and this
Docker image to be in sync. Ideally, we would just always use the latest
release of the current major version, but we can't easily pin this in
the Python requirements because we need an actual hash for `pip`.

It may be that we later:

1. Add a `just` recipe to update the code.
2. Add an automated check to CI to do so.
Add `just` recipe to build outputs with Docker

Rework installation instructions

Split out the Python guide into its own page, and favour the OpenSAFELY
CLI route.
Fix up code formatting

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.
Tidy details of how to update Docker image

Use `docker pull` to fetch Data Builder image

For now, because this will work.

It's because OpenSAFELY CLI needs updating since the Data Builder image is now being published:
opensafely-core/opensafely-cli#158.

pull_request.title: Implement more tutorial refinements
pull_request.body:
This PR makes several improvements to the tutorial content. Primarily these are around installation. We can now get a reader to install a current version of OpenSAFELY CLI and use a  public released Docker `databuilder` image to run the examples.

`opensafely exec` is also referred to for now, with equal prominence to `opensafely run`. In the near future, it is likely that we will favour `opensafely exec`. Rather than wait longer to get these improvements in, it is preferable to merge soon, and then later make those changes.

* Format question prompts consistently
* Switch to using a main release version of Data Builder based on a tag
* Add a `project.yaml`
* Check the dataset definitions run with OpenSAFELY CLI in our CI workflow
* Promote OpenSAFELY CLI as the main route to installing Data Builder in the tutorial, with both `opensafely run` and `opensafely exec` as options

# Tasks

- [x] Update documentation to favour Docker-based `opensafely run` over Python-installed `databuilder generate-dataset`
- [x] Update requirements files
- [x] Add `just` recipe to build outputs with `opensafely`
- [x] Test both ways of generating outputs (OpenSAFELY CLI and Python) in CI
- [x] Review what's the best way to check that outputs are consistent.
- [x] Use `opensafely exec` — going to defer [pending further improvements]( https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246) — but will add a note that it's an option.

comment.body:
As noted in 8da884a25c62ecf461289402ecb3dfc27a3c2e60, one thing I can't fix very quickly is the use of `docker pull` to ensure the reader has the correct Data Builder image.

The OpenSAFELY CLI needs an update. It's not a big problem, but waiting to switch to `opensafely pull` means this PR sits around more. 

In the interests of merging more quickly, and because the installation instructions are a considerable improvement even despite that, I've just stuck with `docker pull`.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -228,14 +200,51 @@ and query that data instead of a backend.
 Each CSV represents a database table.
 Data Builder's CSV loader uses the filename of the CSV
 to determine which Data Builder table it represents.
-For example, a file named `patient_demographics.csv` is interpreted as the Data Builder `patient_demographics` table.
+For example, a file named `patients.csv` is interpreted as the Data Builder `patients` table.
 
 !!! todo
     Add information about loading CSVs elsewhere.
 
-#### Using Data Builder's command-line interface
+#### The OpenSAFELY CLI
+
+With the OpenSAFELY CLI,
+there are currently two ways of running the tutorial dataset definitions:
+
+* `opensafely exec` where the Data Builder configuration is specified at the command line
+* `opensafely run` where the Data Builder configuration is specified in the `project.yaml` file provided in `ehrql-tutorial-examples`
+
+We explain both of these below.
+
+!!! important
+    You only need to use one of these two ways,
+    though you are welcome to try both.
+    We will likely favour the `opensafely exec` route
+    for the tutorial in future
+    and relegate the use of `project.yaml` to the tutorial page that discusses `project.yaml`.
+
+    We are awaiting the improvements in
+    <https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149>
+    before doing so.
+
+#### Using the OpenSAFELY CLI to run a dataset definition via `opensafely exec`
+
+!!! warning
+    This requires:
+    * OpenSAFELY CLI version v1.32.1 or later
+      (run `opensafely upgrade` to upgrade)
+    * Data Builder Docker image v0.57.0 or later
+      (run `opensafely pull` to update if you already have
comment.body: Thanks; now fixed, and updated since that command wouldn't work anyway right now.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,8 +4,56 @@ expectations:
   population_size: 3000
 
 actions:
-  extract_minimal_population:
-    run: databuilder:v0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
+  extract_1a_minimal_population:
+    run: databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
comment.body:
Perhaps! But this is slightly trickier than it looks.

It's deliberately tied to the Python `requirements.dev.txt` for now, to ensure consistency, when running the examples.

1. It's not possible to just specify an equivalent "latest v0 version" for those requirements: we specify hash checks there, which requires that we know what the hash is, and have to keep that updated.
2. If we instead specify a vague tag like `v0` or `dev`, then I assume that this might try and run with an older `v0` or `dev` image, if someone has an older `v0` image already on their machine and doesn't update. If we're at v1 and ensuring no breaking changes, then it might be more reasonable to pin to v1.

In the meantime, we could add an automated workflow in future to keep the images in sync with the requirements specified for Python.

pull_request.title: Remove unnecessary black config
pull_request.body:
By default (according to --help as of v22.8.0) black is already ignoring this list of directories:

/(\.direnv|\.eggs|\.git|\.hg|\.mypy_cache|\.nox|\.tox|\.venv|venv|\.svn|_build|buck-out|build|dist|__pypackages__)/

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

1: https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage_and_configuration/file_collection_and_discovery.html#gitignore

Refs: opensafely-core/repo-template#85

issue.title: Remove unnecessary black config
issue.body:
By default (according to --help as of v22.8.0) black is already ignoring this list of directories:

/(\.direnv|\.eggs|\.git|\.hg|\.mypy_cache|\.nox|\.tox|\.venv|venv|\.svn|_build|buck-out|build|dist|__pypackages__)/

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

1: https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage_and_configuration/file_collection_and_discovery.html#gitignore

Refs: opensafely-core/repo-template#85

comment.body: Just to explain here, because it took me a minute to understand: as mentioned in opensafely-core/repo-template#85, if we remove the `exclude` as this PR does, then the default behaviour for the current version of Black *is* to exclude the files listed in `.gitignore`.

comment.body: In principle, this is fine, Note that we're [currently pinned to a slightly older of Black](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886) due to a conflicting requirement: I'll look at #886 and #1015 when there's a minute, and then we should be able to get up-to-date.

issue.title: Migrate from snex to PyMdown snippet support
issue.body:
Will resolve #886 by removing the extra snex dependency.

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines

issue.title: Unpin black installation
issue.body:
This was pinned in #885; it should be unpinned when possible.

It depends on the version of click used in [snex](https://github.com/jwbargsten/snex): we need snex to upgrade to a version of click that is also compatible with the current versions of black.

comment.body: I think the fix here is to move away from snex to the default support now added to Python Markdown; it removes the extra dependency: https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines :smiley:

pull_request.title: Bump pytest from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pytest](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest) from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pytest's releases.

7.2.0

pytest 7.2.0 (2022-10-23)

Deprecations

  • #10012: Update pytest.PytestUnhandledCoroutineWarning{.interpreted-text role="class"} to a deprecation; it will raise an error in pytest 8.

  • #10396: pytest no longer depends on the py library. pytest provides a vendored copy of py.error and py.path modules but will use the py library if it is installed. If you need other py.* modules, continue to install the deprecated py library separately, otherwise it can usually be removed as a dependency.

  • #4562: Deprecate configuring hook specs/impls using attributes/marks.

    Instead use :pypytest.hookimpl{.interpreted-text role="func"} and :pypytest.hookspec{.interpreted-text role="func"}. For more details, see the docs <legacy-path-hooks-deprecated>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

  • #9886: The functionality for running tests written for nose has been officially deprecated.

    This includes:

    • Plain setup and teardown functions and methods: this might catch users by surprise, as setup() and teardown() are not pytest idioms, but part of the nose support.
    • Setup/teardown using the @​with_setup decorator.

    For more details, consult the deprecation docs <nose-deprecation>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

Features

  • #9897: Added shell-style wildcard support to testpaths.

Improvements

  • #10218: @pytest.mark.parametrize() (and similar functions) now accepts any Sequence[str] for the argument names, instead of just list[str] and tuple[str, ...].

    (Note that str, which is itself a Sequence[str], is still treated as a comma-delimited name list, as before).

  • #10381: The --no-showlocals flag has been added. This can be passed directly to tests to override --showlocals declared through addopts.

  • #3426: Assertion failures with strings in NFC and NFD forms that normalize to the same string now have a dedicated error message detailing the issue, and their utf-8 representation is expresed instead.

  • #7337: A warning is now emitted if a test function returns something other than [None]{.title-ref}. This prevents a common mistake among beginners that expect that returning a [bool]{.title-ref} (for example [return foo(a, b) == result]{.title-ref}) would cause a test to pass or fail, instead of using [assert]{.title-ref}.

  • #8508: Introduce multiline display for warning matching via :pypytest.warns{.interpreted-text role="func"} and enhance match comparison for :py_pytest._code.ExceptionInfo.match{.interpreted-text role="func"} as returned by :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}.

  • #8646: Improve :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}. Previously passing an empty tuple would give a confusing error. We now raise immediately with a more helpful message.

  • #9741: On Python 3.11, use the standard library's tomllib{.interpreted-text role="mod"} to parse TOML.

    tomli{.interpreted-text role="mod"}` is no longer a dependency on Python 3.11.

  • #9742: Display assertion message without escaped newline characters with -vv.

  • #9823: Improved error message that is shown when no collector is found for a given file.

... (truncated)

Commits

  • bc2c3b6 Merge pull request #10408 from NateMeyvis/patch-2
  • d84ed48 Merge pull request #10409 from pytest-dev/asottile-patch-1
  • ffe49ac Merge pull request #10396 from pytest-dev/pylib-hax
  • d352098 allow jobs to pass if codecov.io fails
  • c5c562b Fix typos in CONTRIBUTING.rst
  • d543a45 add deprecation changelog for py library vendoring
  • f341a5c Merge pull request #10407 from NateMeyvis/patch-1
  • 1027dc8 [pre-commit.ci] auto fixes from pre-commit.com hooks
  • 6b905ee Add note on tags to CONTRIBUTING.rst
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

issue.title: Decouple this Repo from cohortextractor

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: cohort extractor
labels.description: Cohort extractor-related documentation issues

issue.body:
We currently install cohortextractor and it's dependencies so we can use automated codegen tooling for pages such as the [variable reference](https://docs.opensafely.org/study-def-variables/).  This means the dev tooling is tied to cohortextractor's requirements, which are not entirely simple.  It also couples cohortextractor to any requirements from this repo.

Databuilder avoided this coupling by exporting a JSON document with all necesssary docs data and having a plugin render it to markdown.

Now that we've proven the technique is workable with databuilder we can move cohortextractor to it as well.

comment.body:
The current state is partly improved. We include cohort-extractor as a submodule. This avoids needing to install it: we only need to process the source.

We could do a similar exporting of JSON from cohort-extractor.

We have also talked about [separating the Data Builder documentation out into the `databuilder` repository](https://github.com/opensafely-core/databuilder/issues/808), though that needs to be trialled and decided.

A similar approach might also work here, but might also not be warranted if we eventually stop adding any new features to cohort-extractor.

issue.title: Consider moving Data Builder docs into Data Builder repository
issue.body:
See [this discussion thread](https://bennettoxford.slack.com/archives/C03FB777L1M/p1659345849579569).

Not sure what form this might take.

Current examples of problems:

* https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886#issuecomment-1204164458
* The tutorial examples are in the documentation repository; this means a user has to download the examples from there. This is not terrible, but is a little eccentric.

issue.title: Add information for cohort-extractor users when learning ehrQL

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The existing tutorial builds up from no prior knowledge of cohort-extractor.

It will probably be useful to include a single page, or a section of multiple pages covering:

* common patterns cohort-extractor users use
* how to implement those patterns in ehrQL
* what is yet to be implemented in Data Builder

comment.body: From experience of comparing two studies, having public studies ported from cohort-extractor to Data Builder would be good, with commit ID or tag marking when the ported study was most representative of its predecessor. (Perhaps the study is one still being developed, and might continue to change.)

commits.message:
Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Make the check outputs recipes only check

Instead of building them.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

issue.title: Add toggle for `--user uid:gid` in `opensafely exec`
issue.body:
As the `exec` option stands, it doesn't work with rootless Docker.

See https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246

comment.body: I'm not sure if this is the best solution, but it works for me.

Add container user environment variable option

This is for a rootless Docker issue.

See https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246

it means that scripts using the "standard" `opensafely exec…` commands
can be made to work without editing the commands themselves.

This is for a rootless Docker issue.

See https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246

This is perhaps preferable to a command line flag:
it means that scripts using the "standard" `opensafely exec…` commands
can be made to work without editing the commands themselves.

The workflow build_and_publish.yaml is referencing action actions/checkout using references v1. However this reference is missing the commit [a6747255bd19d7a757dbdda8c654a9f84db19839](https://github.com/actions/checkout/commits/a6747255bd19d7a757dbdda8c654a9f84db19839) which may contain fix to the some vulnerability. 
The vulnerability fix that is missing by actions version could be related to: 
(1) CVE fix 
(2) upgrade of vulnerable dependency 
(3) fix to secret leak and others. 
Please consider to update the reference to the action.

issue.title: Finish `opensafely exec` implementation
issue.body:
The [long-discussed](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/18) `opensafely exec` command was finally implemented in:
 * #146

But there are further tasks before this is ready for general consumption:
 * Undo the quick fix and implement the proper solution for the "TTY problem" #148
 * Document the `exec` command
 * Rebuild all Docker images from the latest base-docker so they include [this fix](https://github.com/opensafely-core/base-docker/pull/17) which allows them to run as non-root.
 * Check that all images _can_ be run as non-root — they should be able to but there might be some unpleasant surprises that need fixing.
 * Consider the extra features mentioned in the original PR (though we may not want to do any right now):
   - Adding an `--entrypoint` argument to allow customising the image entrypoint for debugging purposes.
   - Passing the appropriate product key for the `stata-mp` image.
   - Setting the `OPENSAFELY_BACKEND` environment variable to `expectations` as the local job-runner does.

comment.body:
## Failed to write output

I tested this out. It looks useful but there's one quirk for me at the moment.

When I tried it as is, with the current `opensafely` (v1.32.1) and Data Builder (v0.57.0), it worked without the `--output` option, but not with.

When I try to write a CSV with the `--output` option, with the latest Data Builder image (v0.57.0), I get a permissions issue:

```sh
$ opensafely exec databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```
```python
…
  File "/app/databuilder/file_formats/csv.py", line 16, in write_dataset_csv
    context = filename.open(mode="w", newline="")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1242, in open
    return io.open(self, mode, buffering, encoding, errors, newline,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1110, in _opener
    return self._accessor.open(self, flags, mode)
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv'
```

The same command with `opensafely run` *does* work:

```
databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```

I believe this is a quirk of me running *rootless* Docker. I think [this very long and ancient open Moby issue partly discusses it](https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/2259). I suspect it's something like: the bind mount has the same uid and gid as the host, but the user in the container is mapped to a different id.

## Workaround

If I modify the `exec.py` to [just remove the `user_args`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/execute.py#L42) that specify `uid` and `gid`, then that does run the command and I can access the output CSV. :heavy_check_mark:

So the quick fix workaround here would be some way of disabling the `--user` part of the command, maybe by an environment variable or command line option.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
We've [standardised on using `just`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/repo-template/blob/b0793ec770f07ca0383bc800d089218d5adacd67/justfile) to help perform some of the routine tasks around repositories (running tests, installing dependencies, other maintenance).

Many of the other repositories we work with benefit with this. It would probably help here too.

issue.title: Inaccurate "tech team are automatically notified" message
issue.body:
This is down to [job-runner's implementation](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/_vendor/jobrunner/run.py#L132-L135). But it manifests locally for users running `opensafely`, so I'll open the issue here.

Under certain conditions (in my case, a Docker failure), you may get an error like:

> ```
> Internal error: this usually means a platform issue rather than a problem for users to fix.
> The tech team are automatically notified of these errors and will be investigating.
> ```

This is:

* *inaccurate* — I'm not running on the platform, and the tech team presumably won't be notified
* *potentially worrying* (even if, as said, it's inaccurate) — "why is the CLI sending information elsewhere?" "where did I agree to this?" "how do I opt out?"

@@ -54,4 +46,17 @@ The `Cohort()` class (imported above) is used to define both the data population
 
 --8<-- 'examples/src-dataset-definition.md'
 
+## How do Dataset definitions work?
+1. **Dataset** is defined in the dataset definition
+2. **Query transformation**: The researcher then loads that dataset
+   definition into Data Builder. Provided the dataset definition is valid, Data Builder transforms
+   the dataset definition into an internal representation of the query called the *query model*.
+
+3. **Query submission**: Data Builder then translates the query model
+   into the appropriate query language for the data backend being
+   accessed. This means that the same dataset definition can be run against
+   multiple backends which may have different structures or underlying software. 
+
+For a more indepth technical explanation of how this works, see [explaining the query engine](explaination-query-engine.md).

commits.message: Format question sections
Try cleaned up Data Builder branch

Change `patient_demographics` to `patients`

This moves to using an equivalent table offered by Data Builder's
universal contract, instead of using a special tutorial table.

This in turn reduces the amount of code needed to be added to Data
Builder to make this import work.

Add a `project.yaml` for all the tutorial code

You can run each individually via `opensafely run <job_name>`

This is a start of moving to using the OpenSAFELY CLI to run all the
dataset definitions, at least for users, to make installation and
running the examples easier.
Ignore OpenSAFELY CLI generated `metadata/`

Update `patient_demographics` in Markdown

To `patients`.
Correct some names in `project.yaml`

Pin Data Builder version to an actual release

Instead of an arbitrary branch commit.

The tables needed to make the examples work are now in the `main` branch
and part of the latest release.

Pin the Docker image used for the examples

For now until a better solution is implemented.

We want the Python installed package in the requirements, and this
Docker image to be in sync. Ideally, we would just always use the latest
release of the current major version, but we can't easily pin this in
the Python requirements because we need an actual hash for `pip`.

It may be that we later:

1. Add a `just` recipe to update the code.
2. Add an automated check to CI to do so.
Add `just` recipe to build outputs with Docker

Rework installation instructions

Split out the Python guide into its own page, and favour the OpenSAFELY
CLI route.
Fix up code formatting

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.
Tidy details of how to update Docker image

Use `docker pull` to fetch Data Builder image

For now, because this will work.

It's because OpenSAFELY CLI needs updating since the Data Builder image is now being published:
opensafely-core/opensafely-cli#158.

pull_request.title: Implement more tutorial refinements
pull_request.body:
This PR makes several improvements to the tutorial content. Primarily these are around installation. We can now get a reader to install a current version of OpenSAFELY CLI and use a  public released Docker `databuilder` image to run the examples.

`opensafely exec` is also referred to for now, with equal prominence to `opensafely run`. In the near future, it is likely that we will favour `opensafely exec`. Rather than wait longer to get these improvements in, it is preferable to merge soon, and then later make those changes.

* Format question prompts consistently
* Switch to using a main release version of Data Builder based on a tag
* Add a `project.yaml`
* Check the dataset definitions run with OpenSAFELY CLI in our CI workflow
* Promote OpenSAFELY CLI as the main route to installing Data Builder in the tutorial, with both `opensafely run` and `opensafely exec` as options

# Tasks

- [x] Update documentation to favour Docker-based `opensafely run` over Python-installed `databuilder generate-dataset`
- [x] Update requirements files
- [x] Add `just` recipe to build outputs with `opensafely`
- [x] Test both ways of generating outputs (OpenSAFELY CLI and Python) in CI
- [x] Review what's the best way to check that outputs are consistent.
- [x] Use `opensafely exec` — going to defer [pending further improvements]( https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246) — but will add a note that it's an option.

comment.body:
As noted in 8da884a25c62ecf461289402ecb3dfc27a3c2e60, one thing I can't fix very quickly is the use of `docker pull` to ensure the reader has the correct Data Builder image.

The OpenSAFELY CLI needs an update. It's not a big problem, but waiting to switch to `opensafely pull` means this PR sits around more. 

In the interests of merging more quickly, and because the installation instructions are a considerable improvement even despite that, I've just stuck with `docker pull`.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -228,14 +200,51 @@ and query that data instead of a backend.
 Each CSV represents a database table.
 Data Builder's CSV loader uses the filename of the CSV
 to determine which Data Builder table it represents.
-For example, a file named `patient_demographics.csv` is interpreted as the Data Builder `patient_demographics` table.
+For example, a file named `patients.csv` is interpreted as the Data Builder `patients` table.
 
 !!! todo
     Add information about loading CSVs elsewhere.
 
-#### Using Data Builder's command-line interface
+#### The OpenSAFELY CLI
+
+With the OpenSAFELY CLI,
+there are currently two ways of running the tutorial dataset definitions:
+
+* `opensafely exec` where the Data Builder configuration is specified at the command line
+* `opensafely run` where the Data Builder configuration is specified in the `project.yaml` file provided in `ehrql-tutorial-examples`
+
+We explain both of these below.
+
+!!! important
+    You only need to use one of these two ways,
+    though you are welcome to try both.
+    We will likely favour the `opensafely exec` route
+    for the tutorial in future
+    and relegate the use of `project.yaml` to the tutorial page that discusses `project.yaml`.
+
+    We are awaiting the improvements in
+    <https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149>
+    before doing so.
+
+#### Using the OpenSAFELY CLI to run a dataset definition via `opensafely exec`
+
+!!! warning
+    This requires:
+    * OpenSAFELY CLI version v1.32.1 or later
+      (run `opensafely upgrade` to upgrade)
+    * Data Builder Docker image v0.57.0 or later
+      (run `opensafely pull` to update if you already have
comment.body: Thanks; now fixed, and updated since that command wouldn't work anyway right now.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,8 +4,56 @@ expectations:
   population_size: 3000
 
 actions:
-  extract_minimal_population:
-    run: databuilder:v0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
+  extract_1a_minimal_population:
+    run: databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
comment.body:
Perhaps! But this is slightly trickier than it looks.

It's deliberately tied to the Python `requirements.dev.txt` for now, to ensure consistency, when running the examples.

1. It's not possible to just specify an equivalent "latest v0 version" for those requirements: we specify hash checks there, which requires that we know what the hash is, and have to keep that updated.
2. If we instead specify a vague tag like `v0` or `dev`, then I assume that this might try and run with an older `v0` or `dev` image, if someone has an older `v0` image already on their machine and doesn't update. If we're at v1 and ensuring no breaking changes, then it might be more reasonable to pin to v1.

In the meantime, we could add an automated workflow in future to keep the images in sync with the requirements specified for Python.

pull_request.title: Remove unnecessary black config
pull_request.body:
By default (according to --help as of v22.8.0) black is already ignoring this list of directories:

/(\.direnv|\.eggs|\.git|\.hg|\.mypy_cache|\.nox|\.tox|\.venv|venv|\.svn|_build|buck-out|build|dist|__pypackages__)/

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

1: https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage_and_configuration/file_collection_and_discovery.html#gitignore

Refs: opensafely-core/repo-template#85

issue.title: Remove unnecessary black config
issue.body:
By default (according to --help as of v22.8.0) black is already ignoring this list of directories:

/(\.direnv|\.eggs|\.git|\.hg|\.mypy_cache|\.nox|\.tox|\.venv|venv|\.svn|_build|buck-out|build|dist|__pypackages__)/

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

1: https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage_and_configuration/file_collection_and_discovery.html#gitignore

Refs: opensafely-core/repo-template#85

comment.body: Just to explain here, because it took me a minute to understand: as mentioned in opensafely-core/repo-template#85, if we remove the `exclude` as this PR does, then the default behaviour for the current version of Black *is* to exclude the files listed in `.gitignore`.

comment.body: In principle, this is fine, Note that we're [currently pinned to a slightly older of Black](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886) due to a conflicting requirement: I'll look at #886 and #1015 when there's a minute, and then we should be able to get up-to-date.

issue.title: Migrate from snex to PyMdown snippet support
issue.body:
Will resolve #886 by removing the extra snex dependency.

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines

issue.title: Unpin black installation
issue.body:
This was pinned in #885; it should be unpinned when possible.

It depends on the version of click used in [snex](https://github.com/jwbargsten/snex): we need snex to upgrade to a version of click that is also compatible with the current versions of black.

comment.body: I think the fix here is to move away from snex to the default support now added to Python Markdown; it removes the extra dependency: https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines :smiley:

pull_request.title: Bump mkdocs-table-reader-plugin from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
pull_request.body:
Bumps [mkdocs-table-reader-plugin](https://github.com/timvink/mkdocs-table-reader-plugin) from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1.

pull_request.title: Bump pytest from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pytest](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest) from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pytest's releases.

7.2.0

pytest 7.2.0 (2022-10-23)

Deprecations

  • #10012: Update pytest.PytestUnhandledCoroutineWarning{.interpreted-text role="class"} to a deprecation; it will raise an error in pytest 8.

  • #10396: pytest no longer depends on the py library. pytest provides a vendored copy of py.error and py.path modules but will use the py library if it is installed. If you need other py.* modules, continue to install the deprecated py library separately, otherwise it can usually be removed as a dependency.

  • #4562: Deprecate configuring hook specs/impls using attributes/marks.

    Instead use :pypytest.hookimpl{.interpreted-text role="func"} and :pypytest.hookspec{.interpreted-text role="func"}. For more details, see the docs <legacy-path-hooks-deprecated>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

  • #9886: The functionality for running tests written for nose has been officially deprecated.

    This includes:

    • Plain setup and teardown functions and methods: this might catch users by surprise, as setup() and teardown() are not pytest idioms, but part of the nose support.
    • Setup/teardown using the @​with_setup decorator.

    For more details, consult the deprecation docs <nose-deprecation>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

Features

  • #9897: Added shell-style wildcard support to testpaths.

Improvements

  • #10218: @pytest.mark.parametrize() (and similar functions) now accepts any Sequence[str] for the argument names, instead of just list[str] and tuple[str, ...].

    (Note that str, which is itself a Sequence[str], is still treated as a comma-delimited name list, as before).

  • #10381: The --no-showlocals flag has been added. This can be passed directly to tests to override --showlocals declared through addopts.

  • #3426: Assertion failures with strings in NFC and NFD forms that normalize to the same string now have a dedicated error message detailing the issue, and their utf-8 representation is expresed instead.

  • #7337: A warning is now emitted if a test function returns something other than [None]{.title-ref}. This prevents a common mistake among beginners that expect that returning a [bool]{.title-ref} (for example [return foo(a, b) == result]{.title-ref}) would cause a test to pass or fail, instead of using [assert]{.title-ref}.

  • #8508: Introduce multiline display for warning matching via :pypytest.warns{.interpreted-text role="func"} and enhance match comparison for :py_pytest._code.ExceptionInfo.match{.interpreted-text role="func"} as returned by :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}.

  • #8646: Improve :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}. Previously passing an empty tuple would give a confusing error. We now raise immediately with a more helpful message.

  • #9741: On Python 3.11, use the standard library's tomllib{.interpreted-text role="mod"} to parse TOML.

    tomli{.interpreted-text role="mod"}` is no longer a dependency on Python 3.11.

  • #9742: Display assertion message without escaped newline characters with -vv.

  • #9823: Improved error message that is shown when no collector is found for a given file.

... (truncated)

  • ffe49ac Merge pull request #10396 from pytest-dev/pylib-hax
  • d352098 allow jobs to pass if codecov.io fails
  • c5c562b Fix typos in CONTRIBUTING.rst
  • d543a45 add deprecation changelog for py library vendoring

issue.title: Decouple this Repo from cohortextractor

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: cohort extractor
labels.description: Cohort extractor-related documentation issues

issue.body:
We currently install cohortextractor and it's dependencies so we can use automated codegen tooling for pages such as the [variable reference](https://docs.opensafely.org/study-def-variables/).  This means the dev tooling is tied to cohortextractor's requirements, which are not entirely simple.  It also couples cohortextractor to any requirements from this repo.

Databuilder avoided this coupling by exporting a JSON document with all necesssary docs data and having a plugin render it to markdown.

Now that we've proven the technique is workable with databuilder we can move cohortextractor to it as well.

comment.body:
The current state is partly improved. We include cohort-extractor as a submodule. This avoids needing to install it: we only need to process the source.

We could do a similar exporting of JSON from cohort-extractor.

We have also talked about [separating the Data Builder documentation out into the `databuilder` repository](https://github.com/opensafely-core/databuilder/issues/808), though that needs to be trialled and decided.

A similar approach might also work here, but might also not be warranted if we eventually stop adding any new features to cohort-extractor.

issue.title: Consider moving Data Builder docs into Data Builder repository
issue.body:
See [this discussion thread](https://bennettoxford.slack.com/archives/C03FB777L1M/p1659345849579569).

Not sure what form this might take.

Current examples of problems:

* https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886#issuecomment-1204164458
* The tutorial examples are in the documentation repository; this means a user has to download the examples from there. This is not terrible, but is a little eccentric.

issue.title: Add information for cohort-extractor users when learning ehrQL

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The existing tutorial builds up from no prior knowledge of cohort-extractor.

It will probably be useful to include a single page, or a section of multiple pages covering:

* common patterns cohort-extractor users use
* how to implement those patterns in ehrQL
* what is yet to be implemented in Data Builder

comment.body: From experience of comparing two studies, having public studies ported from cohort-extractor to Data Builder would be good, with commit ID or tag marking when the ported study was most representative of its predecessor. (Perhaps the study is one still being developed, and might continue to change.)

commits.message:
Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Make the check outputs recipes only check

Instead of building them.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

issue.title: Add toggle for `--user uid:gid` in `opensafely exec`

As the `exec` option stands, it doesn't work with rootless Docker.

comment.body: I'm not sure if this is the best solution, but it works for me.

it means that scripts using the "standard" `opensafely exec…` commands
can be made to work without editing the commands themselves.

(3) fix to secret leak and others. 
Please consider to update the reference to the action.

issue.title: Finish `opensafely exec` implementation
issue.body:
The [long-discussed](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/18) `opensafely exec` command was finally implemented in:
 * #146

But there are further tasks before this is ready for general consumption:
 * Undo the quick fix and implement the proper solution for the "TTY problem" #148
 * Document the `exec` command
 * Rebuild all Docker images from the latest base-docker so they include [this fix](https://github.com/opensafely-core/base-docker/pull/17) which allows them to run as non-root.
 * Check that all images _can_ be run as non-root — they should be able to but there might be some unpleasant surprises that need fixing.
 * Consider the extra features mentioned in the original PR (though we may not want to do any right now):
   - Adding an `--entrypoint` argument to allow customising the image entrypoint for debugging purposes.
   - Passing the appropriate product key for the `stata-mp` image.
   - Setting the `OPENSAFELY_BACKEND` environment variable to `expectations` as the local job-runner does.

comment.body:
## Failed to write output

I tested this out. It looks useful but there's one quirk for me at the moment.

When I tried it as is, with the current `opensafely` (v1.32.1) and Data Builder (v0.57.0), it worked without the `--output` option, but not with.

When I try to write a CSV with the `--output` option, with the latest Data Builder image (v0.57.0), I get a permissions issue:

```sh
$ opensafely exec databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```
```python
…
  File "/app/databuilder/file_formats/csv.py", line 16, in write_dataset_csv
    context = filename.open(mode="w", newline="")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1242, in open
    return io.open(self, mode, buffering, encoding, errors, newline,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1110, in _opener
    return self._accessor.open(self, flags, mode)
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv'
```

The same command with `opensafely run` *does* work:

```
databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```

I believe this is a quirk of me running *rootless* Docker. I think [this very long and ancient open Moby issue partly discusses it](https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/2259). I suspect it's something like: the bind mount has the same uid and gid as the host, but the user in the container is mapped to a different id.

## Workaround

If I modify the `exec.py` to [just remove the `user_args`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/execute.py#L42) that specify `uid` and `gid`, then that does run the command and I can access the output CSV. :heavy_check_mark:

So the quick fix workaround here would be some way of disabling the `--user` part of the command, maybe by an environment variable or command line option.

issue.title: Add a `justfile`

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
We've [standardised on using `just`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/repo-template/blob/b0793ec770f07ca0383bc800d089218d5adacd67/justfile) to help perform some of the routine tasks around repositories (running tests, installing dependencies, other maintenance).

Many of the other repositories we work with benefit with this. It would probably help here too.

issue.title: Inaccurate "tech team are automatically notified" message
issue.body:
This is down to [job-runner's implementation](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/_vendor/jobrunner/run.py#L132-L135). But it manifests locally for users running `opensafely`, so I'll open the issue here.

Under certain conditions (in my case, a Docker failure), you may get an error like:

> ```
> Internal error: this usually means a platform issue rather than a problem for users to fix.
> The tech team are automatically notified of these errors and will be investigating.
> ```

This is:

* *inaccurate* — I'm not running on the platform, and the tech team presumably won't be notified
* *potentially worrying* (even if, as said, it's inaccurate) — "why is the CLI sending information elsewhere?" "where did I agree to this?" "how do I opt out?"

@@ -54,4 +46,17 @@ The `Cohort()` class (imported above) is used to define both the data population
 
 --8<-- 'examples/src-dataset-definition.md'
 
+## How do Dataset definitions work?
+1. **Dataset** is defined in the dataset definition
+2. **Query transformation**: The researcher then loads that dataset
+   definition into Data Builder. Provided the dataset definition is valid, Data Builder transforms
+   the dataset definition into an internal representation of the query called the *query model*.
+
+3. **Query submission**: Data Builder then translates the query model
+   into the appropriate query language for the data backend being
+   accessed. This means that the same dataset definition can be run against
+   multiple backends which may have different structures or underlying software. 
+
+For a more indepth technical explanation of how this works, see [explaining the query engine](explaination-query-engine.md).

commits.message: Format question sections
Try cleaned up Data Builder branch

Change `patient_demographics` to `patients`

This moves to using an equivalent table offered by Data Builder's
universal contract, instead of using a special tutorial table.

This in turn reduces the amount of code needed to be added to Data
Builder to make this import work.

Add a `project.yaml` for all the tutorial code

You can run each individually via `opensafely run <job_name>`

This is a start of moving to using the OpenSAFELY CLI to run all the
dataset definitions, at least for users, to make installation and
running the examples easier.
Ignore OpenSAFELY CLI generated `metadata/`

Update `patient_demographics` in Markdown

To `patients`.
Correct some names in `project.yaml`

Pin Data Builder version to an actual release

Instead of an arbitrary branch commit.

The tables needed to make the examples work are now in the `main` branch
and part of the latest release.

Pin the Docker image used for the examples

For now until a better solution is implemented.

We want the Python installed package in the requirements, and this
Docker image to be in sync. Ideally, we would just always use the latest
release of the current major version, but we can't easily pin this in
the Python requirements because we need an actual hash for `pip`.

It may be that we later:

1. Add a `just` recipe to update the code.
2. Add an automated check to CI to do so.
Add `just` recipe to build outputs with Docker

Rework installation instructions

Split out the Python guide into its own page, and favour the OpenSAFELY
CLI route.
Fix up code formatting

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.
Tidy details of how to update Docker image

Use `docker pull` to fetch Data Builder image

For now, because this will work.

It's because OpenSAFELY CLI needs updating since the Data Builder image is now being published:
opensafely-core/opensafely-cli#158.

pull_request.title: Implement more tutorial refinements
pull_request.body:
This PR makes several improvements to the tutorial content. Primarily these are around installation. We can now get a reader to install a current version of OpenSAFELY CLI and use a  public released Docker `databuilder` image to run the examples.

`opensafely exec` is also referred to for now, with equal prominence to `opensafely run`. In the near future, it is likely that we will favour `opensafely exec`. Rather than wait longer to get these improvements in, it is preferable to merge soon, and then later make those changes.

* Format question prompts consistently
* Switch to using a main release version of Data Builder based on a tag
* Add a `project.yaml`
* Check the dataset definitions run with OpenSAFELY CLI in our CI workflow
* Promote OpenSAFELY CLI as the main route to installing Data Builder in the tutorial, with both `opensafely run` and `opensafely exec` as options

# Tasks

- [x] Update documentation to favour Docker-based `opensafely run` over Python-installed `databuilder generate-dataset`
- [x] Update requirements files
- [x] Add `just` recipe to build outputs with `opensafely`
- [x] Test both ways of generating outputs (OpenSAFELY CLI and Python) in CI
- [x] Review what's the best way to check that outputs are consistent.
- [x] Use `opensafely exec` — going to defer [pending further improvements]( https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/149#issuecomment-1293513246) — but will add a note that it's an option.

As noted in 8da884a25c62ecf461289402ecb3dfc27a3c2e60, one thing I can't fix very quickly is the use of `docker pull` to ensure the reader has the correct Data Builder image.

The OpenSAFELY CLI needs an update. It's not a big problem, but waiting to switch to `opensafely pull` means this PR sits around more. 

In the interests of merging more quickly, and because the installation instructions are a considerable improvement even despite that, I've just stuck with `docker pull`.

 to determine which Data Builder table it represents.

-#### Using Data Builder's command-line interface
+#### The OpenSAFELY CLI
+
+With the OpenSAFELY CLI,
+there are currently two ways of running the tutorial dataset definitions:
+
+* `opensafely exec` where the Data Builder configuration is specified at the command line
+* `opensafely run` where the Data Builder configuration is specified in the `project.yaml` file provided in `ehrql-tutorial-examples`
+

+
+!!! important

+

+
+!!! warning
+    This requires:
+    * OpenSAFELY CLI version v1.32.1 or later
+      (run `opensafely upgrade` to upgrade)
+    * Data Builder Docker image v0.57.0 or later
+      (run `opensafely pull` to update if you already have

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,8 +4,56 @@ expectations:
   population_size: 3000
 
 actions:
-  extract_minimal_population:
-    run: databuilder:v0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
+  extract_1a_minimal_population:
+    run: databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
comment.body:
Perhaps! But this is slightly trickier than it looks.

It's deliberately tied to the Python `requirements.dev.txt` for now, to ensure consistency, when running the examples.

1. It's not possible to just specify an equivalent "latest v0 version" for those requirements: we specify hash checks there, which requires that we know what the hash is, and have to keep that updated.
2. If we instead specify a vague tag like `v0` or `dev`, then I assume that this might try and run with an older `v0` or `dev` image, if someone has an older `v0` image already on their machine and doesn't update. If we're at v1 and ensuring no breaking changes, then it might be more reasonable to pin to v1.

In the meantime, we could add an automated workflow in future to keep the images in sync with the requirements specified for Python.

pull_request.title: Remove unnecessary black config
pull_request.body:
By default (according to --help as of v22.8.0) black is already ignoring this list of directories:

/(\.direnv|\.eggs|\.git|\.hg|\.mypy_cache|\.nox|\.tox|\.venv|venv|\.svn|_build|buck-out|build|dist|__pypackages__)/

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

1: https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage_and_configuration/file_collection_and_discovery.html#gitignore

Refs: opensafely-core/repo-template#85

We were using --exclude which overwrote this list.  Black supports --extend-exclude which builds upon this list and also makes use of the repos .gitignore [1].  Since we we want both git and black to ignore the files for this repo can drop all black config here.

comment.body: Just to explain here, because it took me a minute to understand: as mentioned in opensafely-core/repo-template#85, if we remove the `exclude` as this PR does, then the default behaviour for the current version of Black *is* to exclude the files listed in `.gitignore`.

comment.body: In principle, this is fine, Note that we're [currently pinned to a slightly older of Black](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886) due to a conflicting requirement: I'll look at #886 and #1015 when there's a minute, and then we should be able to get up-to-date.

issue.title: Migrate from snex to PyMdown snippet support
issue.body:
Will resolve #886 by removing the extra snex dependency.

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines

issue.title: Unpin black installation
issue.body:
This was pinned in #885; it should be unpinned when possible.

It depends on the version of click used in [snex](https://github.com/jwbargsten/snex): we need snex to upgrade to a version of click that is also compatible with the current versions of black.

comment.body: I think the fix here is to move away from snex to the default support now added to Python Markdown; it removes the extra dependency: https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-lines :smiley:

pull_request.title: Bump pytest from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pytest](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest) from 7.1.3 to 7.2.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pytest's releases.

7.2.0

pytest 7.2.0 (2022-10-23)

Deprecations

  • #10012: Update pytest.PytestUnhandledCoroutineWarning{.interpreted-text role="class"} to a deprecation; it will raise an error in pytest 8.

  • #10396: pytest no longer depends on the py library. pytest provides a vendored copy of py.error and py.path modules but will use the py library if it is installed. If you need other py.* modules, continue to install the deprecated py library separately, otherwise it can usually be removed as a dependency.

  • #4562: Deprecate configuring hook specs/impls using attributes/marks.

    Instead use :pypytest.hookimpl{.interpreted-text role="func"} and :pypytest.hookspec{.interpreted-text role="func"}. For more details, see the docs <legacy-path-hooks-deprecated>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

  • #9886: The functionality for running tests written for nose has been officially deprecated.

    This includes:

    • Plain setup and teardown functions and methods: this might catch users by surprise, as setup() and teardown() are not pytest idioms, but part of the nose support.
    • Setup/teardown using the @​with_setup decorator.

    For more details, consult the deprecation docs <nose-deprecation>{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

Features

  • #9897: Added shell-style wildcard support to testpaths.

Improvements

  • #10218: @pytest.mark.parametrize() (and similar functions) now accepts any Sequence[str] for the argument names, instead of just list[str] and tuple[str, ...].

    (Note that str, which is itself a Sequence[str], is still treated as a comma-delimited name list, as before).

  • #10381: The --no-showlocals flag has been added. This can be passed directly to tests to override --showlocals declared through addopts.

  • #3426: Assertion failures with strings in NFC and NFD forms that normalize to the same string now have a dedicated error message detailing the issue, and their utf-8 representation is expresed instead.

  • #7337: A warning is now emitted if a test function returns something other than [None]{.title-ref}. This prevents a common mistake among beginners that expect that returning a [bool]{.title-ref} (for example [return foo(a, b) == result]{.title-ref}) would cause a test to pass or fail, instead of using [assert]{.title-ref}.

  • #8508: Introduce multiline display for warning matching via :pypytest.warns{.interpreted-text role="func"} and enhance match comparison for :py_pytest._code.ExceptionInfo.match{.interpreted-text role="func"} as returned by :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}.

  • #8646: Improve :pypytest.raises{.interpreted-text role="func"}. Previously passing an empty tuple would give a confusing error. We now raise immediately with a more helpful message.

  • #9741: On Python 3.11, use the standard library's tomllib{.interpreted-text role="mod"} to parse TOML.

    tomli{.interpreted-text role="mod"}` is no longer a dependency on Python 3.11.

  • #9742: Display assertion message without escaped newline characters with -vv.

  • #9823: Improved error message that is shown when no collector is found for a given file.

... (truncated)

Commits

  • bc2c3b6 Merge pull request #10408 from NateMeyvis/patch-2
  • d84ed48 Merge pull request #10409 from pytest-dev/asottile-patch-1
  • ffe49ac Merge pull request #10396 from pytest-dev/pylib-hax
  • d352098 allow jobs to pass if codecov.io fails
  • c5c562b Fix typos in CONTRIBUTING.rst
  • d543a45 add deprecation changelog for py library vendoring
  • f341a5c Merge pull request #10407 from NateMeyvis/patch-1
  • 1027dc8 [pre-commit.ci] auto fixes from pre-commit.com hooks
  • 6b905ee Add note on tags to CONTRIBUTING.rst
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

issue.title: Decouple this Repo from cohortextractor

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: cohort extractor
labels.description: Cohort extractor-related documentation issues

issue.body:
We currently install cohortextractor and it's dependencies so we can use automated codegen tooling for pages such as the [variable reference](https://docs.opensafely.org/study-def-variables/).  This means the dev tooling is tied to cohortextractor's requirements, which are not entirely simple.  It also couples cohortextractor to any requirements from this repo.

Databuilder avoided this coupling by exporting a JSON document with all necesssary docs data and having a plugin render it to markdown.

Now that we've proven the technique is workable with databuilder we can move cohortextractor to it as well.

comment.body:
The current state is partly improved. We include cohort-extractor as a submodule. This avoids needing to install it: we only need to process the source.

We could do a similar exporting of JSON from cohort-extractor.

We have also talked about [separating the Data Builder documentation out into the `databuilder` repository](https://github.com/opensafely-core/databuilder/issues/808), though that needs to be trialled and decided.

A similar approach might also work here, but might also not be warranted if we eventually stop adding any new features to cohort-extractor.

issue.title: Consider moving Data Builder docs into Data Builder repository
issue.body:
See [this discussion thread](https://bennettoxford.slack.com/archives/C03FB777L1M/p1659345849579569).

Not sure what form this might take.

Current examples of problems:

* https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/886#issuecomment-1204164458
* The tutorial examples are in the documentation repository; this means a user has to download the examples from there. This is not terrible, but is a little eccentric.

issue.title: Add information for cohort-extractor users when learning ehrQL

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The existing tutorial builds up from no prior knowledge of cohort-extractor.

It will probably be useful to include a single page, or a section of multiple pages covering:

* common patterns cohort-extractor users use
* how to implement those patterns in ehrQL
* what is yet to be implemented in Data Builder

comment.body: From experience of comparing two studies, having public studies ported from cohort-extractor to Data Builder would be good, with commit ID or tag marking when the ported study was most representative of its predecessor. (Perhaps the study is one still being developed, and might continue to change.)

commits.message:
Create datasets first in dataset definitions

For consistency.

We should later review the logical order of dataset definitions, but
this is a start.

Stop the check output recipes from building output

Just do the checking and nothing extra.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

Mention `opensafely exec` to run examples

This may need some more polish, so keep both options in for now.
We may later keep the use of `project.yaml` towards the end of the
tutorial for simplicity.

But `opensafely exec` has advantages of:

* being very similar to running `databuilder` via a `pip`-installed
  package
* removing the need for `project.yaml` immediately, which is a
  simplification when getting started

I had issues running it, so I've not done anything like drop the
existing `project.yaml` that covers all dataset definitions.

If we do drop the `project.yaml` for routine running of the tutorial,
we can return to including a simple `project.yaml` just for the minimal
dataset definition. This makes the tutorial exercises for explaining
`project.yaml` more useful.

Clarify use of recipe

We may end up checking with `opensafely exec` too in future.

Check dataset definitions are up-to-date

After the run with OpenSAFELY CLI.

Make the check outputs recipes only check

Instead of building them.

Use Data Builder v0.57.0

This enables using `opensafely exec databuilder…` provided a recent
OpenSAFELY CLI is installed.

issue.body:
The workflow build_and_publish.yaml is referencing action actions/checkout using references v1. However this reference is missing the commit [a6747255bd19d7a757dbdda8c654a9f84db19839](https://github.com/actions/checkout/commits/a6747255bd19d7a757dbdda8c654a9f84db19839) which may contain fix to the some vulnerability. 
The vulnerability fix that is missing by actions version could be related to: 
(1) CVE fix 
(2) upgrade of vulnerable dependency 
(3) fix to secret leak and others. 
Please consider to update the reference to the action.

issue.title: Finish `opensafely exec` implementation
issue.body:
The [long-discussed](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/issues/18) `opensafely exec` command was finally implemented in:
 * #146

But there are further tasks before this is ready for general consumption:
 * Undo the quick fix and implement the proper solution for the "TTY problem" #148
 * Document the `exec` command
 * Rebuild all Docker images from the latest base-docker so they include [this fix](https://github.com/opensafely-core/base-docker/pull/17) which allows them to run as non-root.
 * Check that all images _can_ be run as non-root — they should be able to but there might be some unpleasant surprises that need fixing.
 * Consider the extra features mentioned in the original PR (though we may not want to do any right now):
   - Adding an `--entrypoint` argument to allow customising the image entrypoint for debugging purposes.
   - Passing the appropriate product key for the `stata-mp` image.
   - Setting the `OPENSAFELY_BACKEND` environment variable to `expectations` as the local job-runner does.

comment.body:
## Failed to write output

I tested this out. It looks useful but there's one quirk for me at the moment.

When I tried it as is, with the current `opensafely` (v1.32.1) and Data Builder (v0.57.0), it worked without the `--output` option, but not with.

When I try to write a CSV with the `--output` option, with the latest Data Builder image (v0.57.0), I get a permissions issue:

```sh
$ opensafely exec databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```
```python
…
  File "/app/databuilder/file_formats/csv.py", line 16, in write_dataset_csv
    context = filename.open(mode="w", newline="")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1242, in open
    return io.open(self, mode, buffering, encoding, errors, newline,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/pathlib.py", line 1110, in _opener
    return self._accessor.open(self, flags, mode)
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv'
```

The same command with `opensafely run` *does* work:

```
databuilder:v0.57.0 generate-dataset "./1a_minimal_dataset_definition.py" --dummy-tables "example-data/minimal" --output "outputs/1a_minimal_dataset_definition.csv"
```

I believe this is a quirk of me running *rootless* Docker. I think [this very long and ancient open Moby issue partly discusses it](https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/2259). I suspect it's something like: the bind mount has the same uid and gid as the host, but the user in the container is mapped to a different id.

## Workaround

If I modify the `exec.py` to [just remove the `user_args`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/execute.py#L42) that specify `uid` and `gid`, then that does run the command and I can access the output CSV. :heavy_check_mark:

So the quick fix workaround here would be some way of disabling the `--user` part of the command, maybe by an environment variable or command line option.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
We've [standardised on using `just`](https://github.com/opensafely-core/repo-template/blob/b0793ec770f07ca0383bc800d089218d5adacd67/justfile) to help perform some of the routine tasks around repositories (running tests, installing dependencies, other maintenance).

Many of the other repositories we work with benefit with this. It would probably help here too.

issue.title: Inaccurate "tech team are automatically notified" message
issue.body:
This is down to [job-runner's implementation](https://github.com/opensafely-core/opensafely-cli/blob/da82af0af919344ae80e0533fd6266b52ddcafa1/opensafely/_vendor/jobrunner/run.py#L132-L135). But it manifests locally for users running `opensafely`, so I'll open the issue here.

Under certain conditions (in my case, a Docker failure), you may get an error like:

> ```
> Internal error: this usually means a platform issue rather than a problem for users to fix.
> The tech team are automatically notified of these errors and will be investigating.
> ```

This is:

* *inaccurate* — I'm not running on the platform, and the tech team presumably won't be notified
* *potentially worrying* (even if, as said, it's inaccurate) — "why is the CLI sending information elsewhere?" "where did I agree to this?" "how do I opt out?"

@@ -54,4 +46,17 @@ The `Cohort()` class (imported above) is used to define both the data population
 
 --8<-- 'examples/src-dataset-definition.md'
 
+## How do Dataset definitions work?
+1. **Dataset** is defined in the dataset definition
+2. **Query transformation**: The researcher then loads that dataset
+   definition into Data Builder. Provided the dataset definition is valid, Data Builder transforms
+   the dataset definition into an internal representation of the query called the *query model*.
+
+3. **Query submission**: Data Builder then translates the query model
+   into the appropriate query language for the data backend being
+   accessed. This means that the same dataset definition can be run against
+   multiple backends which may have different structures or underlying software. 
+
+For a more indepth technical explanation of how this works, see [explaining the query engine](explaination-query-engine.md).
